node.title: Federal budget update reveals $7 billion improvement in deficit
node.alt: Josh Frydenberg speaks at a press conference with budget 2021-22 written behind him
node.description: The forecast deficit for this year has been revised down by $7 billion, the Treasurer announces, as theÂ economy recovers from the COVID-19 recession.
node.content:
["A quicker-than-expected economic recovery from the COVID-19 recession has added billions to the government\u2019s bottom line, but that\u2019s unlikely to be felt by workers anytime soon, with the cost of living slated to outstrip wage growth in the coming months.", "In what could be Treasurer Josh Frydenberg\u2019s last major economic update ahead of next year\u2019s election, the Coalition\u2019s mid-year budget sees extra billions flowing into government coffers thanks to the nation bouncing back from shutdowns.", "Mr Frydenberg said Australians had good reason to feel optimistic about the future.", "\"No country is better placed to face the challenges presented by the pandemic,\" he said.", "\"Consumers are spending, businesses are investing and the jobs are coming back.\"", "But that optimism relies heavily on Australia staying ahead of the deadly pandemic, with the government identifying COVID-19 and new variants as the greatest risk to the economy.", "The mid-year economic and fiscal outlook (MYEFO) forecasts real wages are expected to shrink this year, with inflation slated to outstrip wage growth.", "MYEFO forecasts wage growth in 2021-22 will be 0.5 per cent lower than inflation. That reverses in 2022-23, with wage growth 0.5 per cent above inflation.", "
Falling unemployment expected to drive wage growth in future years
", "The government is tipping wages will grow 3.25 per cent in 2024-25, reflecting more optimism in the economic recovery than was expected back in May. \u00a0", "MYEFO also forecasts an improvement in the nation\u2019s unemployment rate, which the government expects will be 4.5 per cent this financial year, falling to 4.25 per cent in the coming years.", "Unemployment hit a six-month high in October, up from 4.6 per cent to 5.2 per cent on the back of people re-entering the workforce after prolonged coronavirus shutdowns in Sydney and Melbourne.", "Figures released on Thursday showed unemployment fell back to 4.6 per cent in November.", "Treasury is forecasting the lower unemployment rate will bring with it wage growth in coming years.", "At the peak of the pandemic, Treasury was warning\u00a0unemployment could hit 15 per cent.\u00a0", "MYEFO includes billions in extra spending that the government is yet to announce, an indication it has budgeted for announcements it will make closer to the election.", "The May budget included $3.8 billion in decisions taken but not yet announced, with another $1.6 billion slated for the 2022-23 financial year.", "However, the mid-year budget includes $16 billion in decisions taken but not yet announced, including $5.5 billion this financial year and $4.1 billion next year.", "
Net debt no longer predicted to peak at $1 trillion
", "MYEFO includes an extra $45.9 billion coming into government coffers this financial year.", "The government will gain an extra $109 billion in the next four years, above earlier forecasts.\u00a0", "This brings with it a downgrading in the forecasted deficits. The government now expects the deficit in 2021-22 will be $99.2 billion, down from the $106 billion forecasted in May.", "However, deficits in future years will largely be in line with what the government forecasted in the budget, except for 2023-24 when the deficit will be $5 billion more.\u00a0", "Net debt is still tipped to peak in 2025 at $914 billion, down from the almost $1 trillion forecasted\u00a0in the budget.\u00a0", "The government is selling the improved budget as thanks to its economic management skills, which it hopes will appeal to voters as the Coalition seeks a fourth term next year.", "Earlier on Thursday, the opposition slammed the Coalition's economic management, arguing living costs had hit new highs while wages stagnated.", "MYEFO forecasts that by June 2025, an extra million people will be in work, an increase of 150,000 forecast in this year's budget.", "Ahead of the last election, Mr Morrison pledged to create 1.25 million jobs over five years, echoing a\u00a0similar pledge former prime minister Tony Abbott made ahead of the 2013 election.", "The opening of the international border, more than six months ahead of what was tipped in the May budget, brings with it an improvement in the migration rate.\u00a0", "Net overseas migration is tipped to fall 41,000 people this year, before increasing to 180,000 next year."]
